averageEffectFollowingHighCauseExplanati: Energy is 2.74/5 (3% lower) on average after days with around 1 ppm Indoor CO2
avgDailyValuePredictingHighOutcomeExplan: Energy is 0%higher after 666 parts per million of Indoor CO2.
avgDailyValuePredictingLowOutcomeExplana: Energy was 0% lower than normal after 666 parts per million of Indoor CO2.
dataAnalysis:
Indoor CO2 Pre-Processing

Indoor CO2 measurement values below 0 parts per million were assumed erroneous and removed. No maximum allowed measurement value was defined for Indoor CO2. No missing data filling value was defined for Indoor CO2 so any gaps in data were just not analyzed instead of assuming zero values for those times.

Energy Pre-Processing

Energy measurement values below 1 out of 5 were assumed erroneous and removed. Energy measurement values above 5 out of 5 were assumed erroneous and removed. No missing data filling value was defined for Energy so any gaps in data were just not analyzed instead of assuming zero values for those times.

Predictive Analytics

It was assumed that 0 seconds would pass before a change in Indoor CO2 would produce an observable change in Energy.

It was assumed that Indoor CO2 could produce an observable change in Energy for as much as 7 days after the stimulus event.

Indoor CO2 Data Quantity

There are currently 1461 raw measurements with 1457 changes spanning 1720 days from 2018-04-17 to 2023-01-02.

Energy Data Quantity

There are currently 1832 raw measurements with 548 changes spanning 3106 days from 2013-01-12 to 2021-07-16.
dataSources:
Indoor CO2 data was primarily collected using Netatmo. Experience the comfort of a Smart Home: Smart Thermostat, Security Camera with Face Recognition, Weather Station.

Energy data was primarily collected using QuantiModo. QuantiModo allows you to easily track mood, symptoms, or any outcome you want to optimize in a fraction of a second. You can also import your data from over 30 other apps and devices. QuantiModo then analyzes your data to identify which hidden factors are most likely to be influencing your mood or symptoms.

participantInstructions:
Get Netatmo here and use it to record your Indoor CO2. Once you have a Netatmo account, you can import your data from the Import Data page.

Your data will automatically be imported and analyzed.


Record your Energy daily
sharingDescription:
Energy was generally 0% higher than average after an average of 669 parts per million of Indoor CO2 over the previous 7 days.

This data suggests with a HIGH degree of confidence (p=0.201, 95% CI -0.082 to 0.084) that Indoor CO2 has a very weakly positive predictive relationship (R=0.0007) with Energy.

The highest quartile of Energy measurements were observed following an average 666 parts per million Indoor CO2.

The lowest quartile of Energy measurements were observed following an average 666 parts per million of Indoor CO2.

After an onset delay of 0 seconds, Energy is typically 0% lower than average over the 7 days following around 666 parts per million Indoor CO2.
significanceExplanation:
Using a two-tailed t-test with alpha = 0.05, it was determined that the change in Energy is not statistically significant at a 95% confidence interval. This suggests that the Indoor CO2 value does not have a significant influence on the Energy value.

After treatment, a 2.1% decrease (-0.0589 out of 5) from the mean baseline 2.85 out of 5 was observed. The relative standard deviation at baseline was 24%. The observed change was 0.0860698 times the standard deviation.

A common rule of thumb considers a change greater than twice the baseline standard deviation on two separate pre-post experiments may be considered significant. This occurrence would have only a 5% likelihood of resulting from random fluctuation (a p-value < 0.05).

The lowest quartile of Energy measurements were observed following an average 666 parts per million of Indoor CO2.

studyBackground: In order to reduce suffering through the advancement of human knowledge, I have chosen to share my findings regarding the relationship between Indoor CO2 and Energy.
studyDesign: This study is based on data donated by one participant. Thus, the study design is consistent with an n=1 observational natural experiment.
studyInvitation: Donate a few seconds a day to help us discover if Indoor CO2 affects Energy!
studyLimitations:
As with any human experiment, it was impossible to control for all potentially confounding variables. Correlation does not necessarily imply causation. We can never know for sure if one factor is definitely the cause of an outcome. However, lack of correlation definitely implies the lack of a causal relationship. Hence, we can with great confidence rule out non-existent relationships. For instance, if we discover no relationship between mood and an antidepressant this information is just as or even more valuable than the discovery that there is a relationship.

We can also take advantage of several characteristics of time series data from many subjects to infer the likelihood of a causal relationship if we do find a correlational relationship. The criteria for causation are a group of minimal conditions necessary to provide adequate evidence of a causal relationship between an incidence and a possible consequence.

Criteria For Causal Inference

Strength (A.K.A. Effect Size)

A small association does not mean that there is not a causal effect, though the larger the association, the more likely that it is causal. There is a very weakly positive (R = 0.0007) relationship between Indoor CO2 and Energy.

Consistency (A.K.A. Reproducibility)

Consistent findings observed by different persons in different places with different samples strengthens the likelihood of an effect. Furthermore, in accordance with the law of large numbers (LLN), the predictive power and accuracy of these results will continually grow over time. 743 paired data points were used in this analysis. Assuming that the relationship is merely coincidental, as the participant independently modifies their Indoor CO2 values, the observed strength of the relationship will decline until it is below the threshold of significance. To it another way, in the case that we do find a spurious correlation, suggesting that banana intake improves mood for instance, one will likely increase their banana intake. Due to the fact that this correlation is spurious, it is unlikely that you will see a continued and persistent corresponding increase in mood. So over time, the spurious correlation will naturally dissipate.

Specificity

Causation is likely if a very specific population at a specific site and disease with no other likely explanation. The more specific an association between a factor and an effect is, the bigger the probability of a causal relationship.

Temporality

The effect has to occur after the cause (and if there is an expected delay between the cause and expected effect, then the effect must occur after that delay). The confidence in a causal relationship is bolstered by the fact that time-precedence was taken into account in all calculations.

Biological Gradient

Greater exposure should generally lead to greater incidence of the effect. However, in some cases, the mere presence of the factor can trigger the effect. In other cases, an inverse proportion is observed: greater exposure leads to lower incidence.

Plausibility

A plausible bio-chemical mechanism between cause and effect is critical. This is where human brains excel.

Based on our responses so far,

0 humans feel that there is a plausible mechanism of action for a relationship between Indoor CO2 and Energy.

0 humans feel that any relationship observed between Indoor CO2 and Energy is coincidental.

Coherence

Coherence between epidemiological and laboratory findings increases the likelihood of an effect. It will be very enlightening to aggregate this data with the data from other participants with similar genetic, diseasomic, environmentomic, and demographic profiles.

Experiment

All of human life can be considered a natural experiment. Occasionally, it is possible to appeal to experimental evidence.

Analogy

The effect of similar factors may be considered.
studyObjective: The objective of this study is to determine the nature of the relationship (if any) between Indoor CO2 and Energy. Additionally, we attempt to determine the Indoor CO2 values most likely to produce optimal Energy values.
studyResults:
This analysis suggests that higher Indoor CO2 (Environment) generally predicts higher Energy (p=0.201, 95% CI -0.082 to 0.084)

Energy is0% higher after around 666 parts per million Indoor CO2.

After an onset delay of 0 seconds, Energy is generally 0% than its average over the 7 days following around 666 parts per million Indoor CO2.

INDOOR CO2 Data Quantity: There are 1461 raw Indoor CO2 measurements. There are 1461 Indoor CO2 measurements when you include those derived from tagged duplicate, child or ingredient variables and those derived from zero filling gaps in data. There 1457 changes spanning 1720 days from 2018-04-17 to 2023-01-02. ENERGY Data Quantity: There are 1832 raw Energy measurements. There are 1832 Energy measurements when you include those derived from tagged duplicate, child or ingredient variables and those derived from zero filling gaps in data. There 548 changes spanning 3106 days from 2013-01-12 to 2021-07-16.

The top quartile outcome values are preceded by an average 666 parts per million of Indoor CO2.

The bottom quartile outcome values are preceded by an average 666 parts per million of Indoor CO2.

The Forward Pearson Predictive Coefficient was 0.0007((p=0.201, 95% CI -0.082 to 0.084) , onset delay = 0 seconds, duration of action = 7 days).

The Reverse Pearson Predictive Coefficient was (0.20126529569473, 95% CI -0.083 to 0.083, onset delay = -0 seconds, duration of action = -7 days).

When the Indoor CO2 value is closer to 666 parts per million than 666 parts per million, the Energy value which follows is 0 percent higher than its typical value.

When the Indoor CO2 value is closer to 666 parts per million than 666 parts per million, the Energy value which follows is generally 0% than its typical value.

Energy is 2.74/5 (3% lower) on average after days with around 1 ppm Indoor CO2
studyTitle: Higher Indoor CO2 Predicts Very Slightly Higher Energy
tagLine: Energy was generally 2.1% lower following above average Indoor CO2 over the previous 7 days.
